title: Is the Educated Elite Out of Touch with America?
description: In this episode, we explore the growing disconnect between America's educated professional class and the rest of the country, analyzing how this divide impacts politics and society. Inspired by insights from the Noahpinion blog.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial,' where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we're diving into a conversation that goes beyond tech and ventures into the fabric of American society. Our topic stems from an insightful blog post by Noah Smith, on his blog Noahpinion, titled 'The Educated Professional Class is Out of Touch with America.' This piece is a response to recent shifts in U.S. politics, especially the divide between the highly educated and the rest of the country. You can find the full article at www.noahpinion.blog. So let’s talk about why the professional class might be losing touch and what this means for America.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: In the article, Noah Smith discusses how the Democrats’ core base has been shifting away from the working class and increasingly attracting the highly educated professional class. This shift has created a divide that some say is becoming a fundamental problem for Democrats when it comes to reaching voters without college degrees. It’s something that, interestingly enough, even recent U.S. elections have highlighted. Trump and the GOP are winning more support from non-college voters, including certain Hispanic groups and even urban populations. Meanwhile, Democrats find themselves holding onto an educated base but struggling to connect with a broader audience.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So why does this divide matter? Well, if we look at the big picture, it reveals a significant gap in values, beliefs, and even the kinds of information people consume. According to Smith, this split between the professional class and the rest of America has grown over the years, contributing to a deeply polarized political landscape.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Smith argues that many of the issues that concern Trump’s base are ones that hit the working class harder than they do educated professionals. Things like inflation, public safety, and a sense of national identity often resonate more with these voters than with highly educated, urban professionals. For many in the professional class, ideas around social justice, environmental policies, and immigration reform are front and center. These are undeniably important issues, but the concern is that they may sometimes seem disconnected from the everyday struggles of working-class Americans.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: There’s also an element of 'performative activism' among the educated elite—where certain causes and values are almost worn like a badge of honor. Take, for example, support for social justice initiatives or efforts to curb climate change. They’ve become cultural cornerstones within educated circles, but for people facing immediate issues like job insecurity or rising costs, they can seem distant or even alienating.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Smith points out that the educated class has traditionally expected the percentage of college graduates to continue rising, assuming that education would naturally bring more voters into their base. But data shows otherwise. College enrollment has been dropping, and recent figures reveal that fewer Americans are graduating from college than in past years. Why? Because rising tuition and decreasing wage benefits make college less attractive.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: And the disconnect doesn’t stop there. With fewer people viewing college as a gateway to economic success, the traditional assumptions about an ever-growing professional class simply don’t hold up. This could mean that, long-term, the Democratic Party faces an uphill battle if it doesn’t find a way to speak to non-college voters in a way that resonates.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: One interesting twist is the shift among some tech elites. Recently, figures like Elon Musk and David Sacks have started showing support for Trump and the GOP. This suggests a potential shift among even some in the educated elite, possibly driven by frustrations with what they see as overly 'woke' attitudes among progressive circles.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: What we’re seeing here is not just a political division but a cultural one. The highly educated have grown up in environments—universities, media circles—where progressive ideals are prevalent, sometimes to the point where they become cultural norms. But that’s not the lived reality for a majority of Americans, and Smith believes that’s where Democrats might be losing touch.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So what does all of this mean for the future? Smith suggests that Democrats might need to rethink their messaging if they want to attract non-college voters. This doesn’t mean abandoning important causes, but rather communicating in a way that addresses immediate, real-world concerns, without appearing disconnected or dismissive.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Ultimately, it’s a question of bridging the cultural divide. It’s about understanding that what works for the educated elite might not resonate in the same way with other Americans. Finding that common ground, in a society as diverse as the U.S., is no small task. But as the article implies, it could be key to forging a more united future.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Thank you for tuning into this episode of 'Life is Artificial.' If you’re interested in more on this topic, I highly recommend reading Noah Smith’s full article, 'The Educated Professional Class is Out of Touch with America,' on Noahpinion. The link is in the episode description.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: As always, stay curious, and we’ll see you next time.
